questions.text: A 62-year-old male on warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation presents with uncontrolled bleeding. Laboratory tests show prolonged PT and INR. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the effect of warfarin on coagulation?

choices.text: Inhibition of Vitamin K epoxide reductase

questions.solution:
Warfarin acts as an anticoagulant by inhibiting the enzyme Vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is crucial for the Vitamin K cycle.

It is responsible for the reduction of Vitamin K epoxide back to Vitamin K hydroquinone, the active form of Vitamin K. This inhibition disrupts the carboxylation of Vitamin K-dependent clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, impairing their function and leading to prolonged PT and INR, which manifests as a bleeding tendency.

Warfarin decreases both Protein C and Protein S, temporarily increasing the risk of thrombosis when treatment is initiated. Careful monitoring is essential during this period.

Vitamin K Cycle:

Inhibition of thrombin activity directly (Option B): Warfarin does not directly inhibit thrombin activity. Instead, it reduces the synthesis of thrombin's precursor, prothrombin (Factor II), necessary for its activation.

Binding to calcium ions (Option C): Vitamin K-dependent clotting factors require calcium ions for activation, but warfarin does not work by binding to calcium.

Direct inhibition of clotting factors (Option D): Warfarin indirectly prevents the synthesis of clotting factors by inhibiting their necessary γ-carboxylation, a process dependent on Vitamin K recycling.

questions.text: A 40 year old woman presents with complaints of persistent nausea, vomiting, and frequent urination over the past few weeks. She has a history of osteomalacia and has been taking supplements for several months without proper medical supervision. Her blood tests reveal elevated serum calcium levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vitamin D toxicity aligns with the patient's history of high supplement intake, most probably containing Vitamin D, and her symptoms of nausea, vomiting, frequent urination, and hypercalcemia.

Comparison of Vitamin D Toxicity and Deficiency:

Aspect

Vitamin D Deficiency

Vitamin D Toxicity

Causes

Inadequate dietary intake, insufficient sun exposure, malabsorption syndromes, and certain medical conditions affecting metabolism.

Excessive supplementation.

Dietary intake and sun exposure rarely cause toxicity.

Symptoms

Bone pain, muscle weakness, and increased risk of fractures; in children, it leads to rickets; in adults, it leads to osteomalacia or osteoporosis.

Nausea, vomiting, weakness, frequent urination, and hypercalcemia; can lead to kidney stones and kidney damage.

Serum Levels

Defined as 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) < 30 ng/mL, indicating insufficient levels.

Occurs when 25(OH)D > 150 ng/mL, leading to adverse health effects.

Treatment

Managed with dietary supplementation via food or medications and increased sun exposure.

Requires discontinuation of vitamin D intake, intravenous fluids, and medications, such as corticosteroids or bisphosphonates.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option A) typically presents with elevated serum calcium due to increased parathyroid hormone but is less likely given the context of high supplement intake.

Vitamin D deficiency (Option B) would not cause hypercalcemia; rather, it leads to bone pain, muscle weakness, and increased fracture risk.

Hypercalcemia of malignancy (Option D) can cause elevated serum calcium but does not fit the clinical context of excessive Vitamin D supplementation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a commonly associated symptom with vitamin E deficiency?
questions.solution:
Megaloblastic anemia is caused due to deficiency of vitamin B9 (folic acid) and B12 (cobalamin)

Vitamin E Deficiency:

  • Rare but seen in severe fat malabsorption, cystic fibrosis and some forms of chronic liver disease, as these conditions are unable to absorb or transport vitamin E.
  • Premature infants are born with inadequate vitamin E reserves.
  • Symptoms:
    • Hemolytic anemia: Due to lipid peroxidation and fragile erythrocyte membranes. (Option D ruled out)
    • Neurological problems due to poor nerve conduction:
  • Spinocerebellar ataxia (Option A ruled out)
  • Retinopathy
  • Peripheral neuropathy (Option C ruled out)
  • Myopathies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fatigue, frequent urination, constipation, and confusion. His laboratory results show hypercalcemia and low serum parathyroid hormone level. He reports taking high-dose, over-the-counter vitamin D supplements for the past year. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with his current presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Increased risk of hypertension

 

Explanation:

 

 

The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with vitamin D toxicity. Excessive vitamin D intake can lead to hypercalcemia, which can manifest as fatigue, frequent urination, constipation, and confusion. Hypercalcemia causes high blood pressure. Vitamin D toxicity also causes low serum parathyroid hormone levels.

Vitamin D Toxicity:

  • Vitamin D toxicity is defined as Adults > 4000 IU and children > 2000 IU.
  • Calcium homeostasis:
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Thickening of the long bones
    • Calcification of soft tissues (Calcinosis).
    • Calcium deposition in Blood vessels (Monckeberg medial calcific sclerosis, atherosclerosis, etc)
  • Hypercalcemia: Contraction of blood vessels and High blood pressure. (Option A)
  • While excessive dietary vitamin D is toxic, overexposure to sunlight does not cause vitamin D poisoning.

Beneficial effects of High Vitamin D status:

  • Protects against prediabetes and metabolic syndrome.(Option D ruled out)
  • Protect against various cancers:
    • Prostate cancer
    • Colorectal cancer (Option B ruled out)
    • Breast cancer (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 38-year-old female with a history of chronic kidney disease presents with persistent fatigue, bone pain, and muscle weakness. Blood work reveals elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP), high serum phosphorus, and low serum calcium. What will the result of 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D likely reveal?

choices.text: Estimating 1, 25 dihydroxy vitamin D is unnecessary.

questions.solution:
Patients with CKD often have reduced 1α-hydroxylase, leading to lower levels of active vitamin D: 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D.

1,25 dihydroxy Vitamin D in Chronic kidney disease:

  • In chronic kidney disease (CKD), estimating 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D levels is essential due to the kidneys' role in vitamin D metabolism. (Option B ruled out)
  • The kidneys are the primary site where 1α-hydroxylase converts inactive vitamin D (25 hydroxy cholecalciferol) into its active form, 1,25 dihydroxy cholecalciferol.
  • Patients with CKD often have reduced 1α-hydroxylase, leading to lower levels of active vitamin D: 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D. (Options A and D ruled out)
  • Impact on Calcium Homeostasis: Low levels in CKD causes hypocalcemia.
  • Secondary Hyperparathyroidism: To compensate for low calcium, PTH increases and has negative consequences for bone health.
  • Renal Osteodystrophy: Abnormal bone turnover, as evidenced by the elevated alkaline phosphatase in the clinical scenario.
  • Diagnostic Value: 1,25 dihydroxy cholecalciferol has a longer half-life and remains stable. Therefore, it provides a more reliable test for vitamin D status in CKD and helps guide appropriate treatment.
  • Treatment:
    • Dialysis.
    • Calcimimetic drugs - Cinacalcet and Etelcalcetide.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with progressive bowing of the legs and tenderness in the lower limbs. The child has a history of limited outdoor play and a diet low in dairy products. Which of the following limb deformities is most likely present in this child?
questions.solution:
The scenario describes a child with classic signs of Rickets associated with vitamin D deficiency. This condition results in leg deformities in children with inadequate sun exposure and dietary intake of vitamin D.

Clinical manifestations of Vitamin D deficiency

Rickets (Option A)
  • Occurs in children.
  • Inadequate bone mineralization due to poor calcium absorption.
  • Bones become soft and weak, leading to deformities under pressure.
  • Clinical signs:
    • Muscle weakness
    • Delayed walking
    • Skeletal deformities - "pigeon chest" (pectus carinatum) and genu varus (bowed legs), Genu valgum, windswept deformity.
    • Rickety rosary

Osteomalacia (Option C ruled out)
  • Occurs in adults.
  • Demineralization of bone, making them weak and prone to fractures.
  • Risk factors: limited sun exposure, women after multiple pregnancies.

Renal osteodystrophy

Long-standing secondary hyperparathyroidism can result in renal osteodystrophy, increasing the risk of pathological fractures.

 

Blount’s disease (Option B) (tibia vara) is an acquired genu varus deformity typically developing later in childhood, while nutritional rickets, caused by vitamin D deficiency from poor diet and limited sun exposure, is more likely in this young child.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D) is unlikely because it is a genetic disorder affecting collagen synthesis, leading to brittle bones and frequent fractures from birth, rather than the progressive bowing of the legs seen in nutritional rickets.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, and bone pain for the past several months. She has a history of hypothyroidism and is currently taking levothyroxine. She lives in North India and avoids dairy products. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness over her shins. Laboratory tests reveal:


	
		
			
			Serum calcium
			
			
			8.2 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5-10.5 mg/dL)
			
		
		
			
			Serum phosphorus
			
			
			2.0 mg/dL (normal range: 2.5-4.5 mg/dL)
			
		
		
			
			Parathyroid hormone (PTH)
			
			
			Elevated
			
		
	


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the above scenario, the patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are most likely to be Vitamin D deficiency.

Blood findings of Vitamin D deficiency

Biochemical Feature

Explanation

Hypocalcemia

Due to decreased calcium absorption in the intestine.

Hypophosphatemia

Due to decreased phosphate absorption in the intestine and decreased reabsorption of phosphate in the kidneys.

Secondary Hyperparathyroidism

In response to low calcium levels, the parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases, which increases calcium reabsorption from bone and the kidneys.

Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)

Due to Increased bone turnover as a result of increased PTH.

25-hydroxy cholecalciferol

Decreased.

 

Prolonged secondary hyperparathyroidism can cause renal osteodystrophy, which may lead to pathological fractures.

Primary hyperparathyroidism (Option B) leads to excess PTH production, causing hypercalcemia.

Hypoparathyroidism (Option C) presents with low PTH and hypocalcemia. Hypothyroidism is commonly associated with vitamin D deficiency, potentially due to immune dysfunction and impacts on calcium metabolism

Chronic kidney disease (Option D) causes secondary hyperparathyroidism due to impaired phosphate excretion and low 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D levels, it is typically associated with hyperphosphatemia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with muscle cramps and tingling in her hands and feet. She follows a strict vegetarian diet high in whole grains and has a history of fat malabsorption due to IBS. Lab tests reveal hypocalcemia and low vitamin D levels. What is the most likely cause of her hypocalcemia?
questions.solution:
Phytates, found in high amounts in whole grains and cereals, bind calcium in the intestine, preventing its absorption. Since the patient’s diet is rich in these foods, the phytates are likely reducing her calcium absorption.

Vitamin D and Calcium Absorption:

  • Vitamin D is essential for intestinal calcium absorption.
  • It induces the synthesis of calbindin, a protein crucial for calcium absorption. (Option D ruled out)
  • Vitamin D recruits calcium transporters to the cell surface, enhancing absorption rapidly, independent of new protein synthesis.

Factors Inhibiting Calcium Absorption:

  • Phytic Acid: Found in cereals, it binds calcium in the intestine, preventing absorption.
  • Unleavened Whole-Wheat Products: High in phytate, which binds to calcium, preventing absorption. (Option C)
  • Fatty Acids: High levels in the intestine can form insoluble calcium salts, reducing absorption. (Option B ruled out)
  • Oxalate: High intake can cause calcium deficiency by forming insoluble calcium oxalate. (Option A ruled out)

Role of vitamin D in calcium metabolism:

Intestine
  • Enterocytes directly absorb calcium by active transport (Option B ruled out)
  • Upregulates calbindin (Option C)

Bone
  • Osteoblasts get activated directly and help in the mineralization of the bone
  • Indirectly activates osteoclasts

Kidney
  • Increases calcium and phosphate reabsorption

questions.text: Which of the following factors does not inhibit 1α-hydroxylase activity?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) High parathormone

Explanation:

 

The parathyroid hormone has a positive effect on 1 alpha-hydroxylase enzyme, which enhances the conversion of 25(OH)2-D3 to 1,25(OH)2-D3.

Regulation of Vit-D synthesis:

  • The rate-limiting step of vitamin D synthesis is the conversion of 25(OH)2-D3 to 1,25(OH)2-D3 via 1-α hydroxylase enzyme.
  • 1-α hydroxylase gets activated by parathyroid hormone (Option C).
  • High calcium and phosphate levels inactivate 1-α hydroxylase activity. (Options A and B ruled out)
  • 1,25-DH vit D increases calcium levels, which in turn inactivates 1-α hydroxylase (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: Identify the enzymes marked as a and b respectively in the flow chart, as related to vitamin D synthesis:

choices.text: α-25 alpha hydroxylase, liver; β-1 alpha hydroxylase, kidney
α-1 alpha hydroxylase, kidney ; β-25 alpha hydroxylase, liver
α-1 alpha hydroxylase, liver; β-25 alpha hydroxylase, kidney
α-25 alpha hydroxylase, kidney; β-1 alpha-hydroxylase, liver

questions.solution:
Vitamin D synthesis:

(a: α- 25 alpha hydroxylase; b: β-1 alpha hydroxylase)

  • Skin:
    • Most of the precursors for 1,25(OH)2-D3 synthesis is produced in the malpighian layer of epidermis from 7-dehydrocholesterol via UV light-mediated photolysis reaction.
    • Conversion efficiency is affected by UV exposure and skin pigmentation.
    • Aging reduces 7-dehydrocholesterol levels.
  • Liver:
    • Vitamin D is transported to the liver by vitamin D-binding protein.
    • In the liver, vitamin D is hydroxylated to 25(OH)2-D3 (25 dihydroxy cholecalciferol) by 25 alpha-hydroxylase.
    • This process requires magnesium, NADPH, molecular oxygen and an uncharacterized cytoplasmic factor.
    • Two enzymes involved: NADPH-dependent cytochrome P450 reductase and cytochrome P450.
    • 25(OH)2-D3 is the main circulating form of vitamin D and is transported to the kidney.
  • Kidney:
    • 25(OH)D3 is converted to the active form, 1,25(OH)2D3 (1,25 dihydroxy cholecalciferol), in the kidneys by the enzyme 1 alpha-hydroxylase.
    • This conversion involves a three-component monooxygenase system requiring NADPH, magnesium, molecular oxygen, and three enzymes: renal ferredoxin reductase, renal ferredoxin, and cytochrome P450.
    • 1,25(OH)2D3 is the most potent active metabolite of vitamin D.

questions.text: Which of the following features is NOT associated with a deficiency of Vitamin K?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C)Hyperbilirubinemia

Explanation: 

Hyperbilirubinemia is not associated with vitamin K deficiency. Instead, it is related to vitamin K toxicity, particularly in newborns, leading to conditions like hemolysis and kernicterus.

Vitamin K Deficiency

Vitamin K Toxicity

Causes:

  • Fat malabsorption (e.g., cystic fibrosis)
  • Pancreatic insufficiency

Causes:

  • High doses of vitamin K
  • Vitamin E deficiency

Manifestations:

  • Bleeding mucous membrane (Option D ruled out)
  • Increased PT and Bleeding time. (Option B ruled out)
  • Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (Option A ruled out)

Manifestations:

  • Hemolytic anemia similar to Vitamin E deficiency
  • Hemolytic anemia ➜ Hemolytic jaundice ➜ Kernicterus and brain damage.

questions.text: Which vitamins are least likely to accumulate in the body's adipose tissue due to its solubility characteristics?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid is a water-soluble vitamin (B5) and is not stored in significant amounts in adipose tissue. Water-soluble vitamins are generally excreted in the urine and do not accumulate in the body.
 

Vitamin

Sources

A

  • Retinol
  • Retinal
  • Retinoic acid
  • Beta-carotene

Milk, butter, cream, cheese, egg yolk, Beta carotene, carrots, papaya

D

  • Ergocalciferol (Vitamin D2)
  • Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3)

Fish liver oil, fish, egg yolk, milk

E

  • Tocopherol (specifically, alpha-tocopherol)

Vegetable oil, Wheat germ oil, sunflower oil, safflower oil, cottonseed oil

K

  • Phylloquinone (Vitamin K1)
  • Menaquinone (Vitamin K2)
  • Menadione (Vitamin K3, a synthetic form)

Phylloquinone: Green vegetables

Menaquinones: Synthesized by intestinal bacteria

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Vitamin K is incorrect?

choices.text: Vitamin K is crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors.
Vitamin K2 is a lipid-soluble form produced by intestinal bacteria.
Menadione is a natural water-soluble form of Vitamin K.
Vitamin K aids in the carboxylation of bone proteins.

questions.solution:
Menadione is a water-soluble form of Vitamin K widely used in clinical practice. It can be metabolised to Phylloquinone, but it’s a Synthetic form, not a natural form.

Vitamin K:

  • Fat-soluble vitamin that acts as a coenzyme or prosthetic group for gamma-carboxylase.
  • Calcium-dependent proteins that rely on Vitamin K:
    • Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. (Option A ruled out)
    • Anticoagulant factors like protein C and S.
    • Osteocalcin (promotes bone mineralization by depositing calcium).
  • Forms of Vitamin K:
    • Phylloquinone (K1): Found in green vegetables, this form has an isoprenoid side chain with 20 carbons.
    • Menaquinones (K2): Synthesized by intestinal bacteria, these have varying side chain lengths and an isoprenoid side chain containing 30 carbons, which is lipid soluble. (Option B ruled out)
    • Menadione (K3): A synthetic form which is water-soluble. Menadione and menadione diacetate can be metabolized into phylloquinone.
  • Vitamin K exists in two forms: Epoxide and Hydroquinone form.
  • Functions:
    • Blood Clotting.
    • Bone Health - Carboxylating glutamate to glutamic acid in proteins like osteocalcin is involved in bone mineralization. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following are deficiency manifestations of Vitamin E except:
questions.solution:
Vitamin E Toxicity:

  1. Interference with Vitamin K: Antagonize vitamin K, impairing blood coagulation and increasing bleeding risk.
  2. Interaction with Warfarin: Enhance the anticoagulant effect of warfarin, leading to a greater risk of bleeding complications.
  3. Effects on Platelet Aggregation: Vitamin E may impair platelet function, potentially increasing the risk of bleeding.
  4. Enterocolitis in Infants: Associated with an increased risk of necrotizing enterocolitis in premature infants.

Vitamin E Deficiency

  

1. Hemolytic anemia
 
  • Due to the destruction of red blood cells by oxidative stress.
  • Vitamin E acts as an antioxidant that protects cell membranes from damage by free radicals​.

2. Spinocerebellar ataxia (Option A ruled out)
  • Degeneration of the cerebellum and spinal cord leading to imbalance, incoordination and ataxia.

3. Peripheral Neuropathy (Option D ruled out)
  • Insufficient antioxidant protection damages peripheral nerves, leading to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, and muscle weakness​.

4. Eyes
  • Pigment retinopathy
  • Ophthalmoplegia (Option B ruled out)
  • Nystagmus

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a chain-breaking antioxidant?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D- Glutathione Peroxidase

Glutathione Peroxidase is a preventive antioxidant, not a chain-breaking antioxidant.

Antioxidants are substances that help control and reduce lipid peroxidation by neutralizing free radicals, which can cause cellular damage.

Classification of Antioxidants:

1. Preventive Antioxidants:
  • Reduce the rate of chain initiation.
  • Examples:
    • Glutathione Peroxidase (Option D)
    • Catalase
    • Selenium

2. Chain-Breaking Antioxidants (Option A, B and C ruled out):
  • Interfere with chain propagation by stabilizing free radicals.
  • Examples:
    • α-Tocopherol (Vitamin E)
    • β-Carotene (Vitamin A)
    • Vitamin C
    • Superoxide Dismutase (SOD)

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with severe acne on her face and back. She was previously treated with benzoyl peroxide and oral doxycycline and found no improvement. Physical examination shows comedones, pustules, inflammatory papules, and facial scarring. Which of the following is the next best treatment?
questions.solution:
13 cis retinoic acid (isotretinoin) is used to treat nodulocystic acne, which is refractory to treatment with topical medication and oral antibiotics.

13 cis retinoic acid (isotretinoin):

Mechanism
  • Inhibits sebum production
  • Inhibit keratinocyte proliferation

Use

Nodulocystic acne

Adverse effects
  • Dry skin
  • Headache
  • Alopecia
  • Idiopathic intracranial hypertension
  • Teratogenic

Contraindications
  • Pregnancy
  • Liver disease

Precautions

  • Negative pregnancy test
  • Two contraception methods

All trans-retinoic acid (Option A):

  • Used for Acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3).
  • Binds to retinoic acid receptors, inducing cell differentiation.

Tocopherol (Option B):

  • Antioxidant (prevents free radical damage).
  • Used in Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis. (NASH)

Phylloquinone (Option C):

  • Known as vitamin K1 (Other forms: Menadione, menaquinone (K2) )
  • Cofactor for gamma-carboxylation of coagulation.
  • Deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely observed in patients with vitamin A toxicity?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A toxicity

Causes:

  • Excessive vitamin A supplementation
  • Increased polar bear liver consumption

Mechanism:

  • Excessive vitamin A intake leads to accumulation beyond the capacity of binding proteins, causing membrane lysis and tissue damage.
  • Higher concentrations of retinol increase lysosomal enzymes, leading to cellular death.

Symptoms:

1. Central Nervous System:

  • Headache
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Ataxia
  • Anorexia (Option D ruled out)
  • Increased cerebrospinal fluid pressure, which mimics symptoms of brain tumor (pseudotumor cerebri) (Option A ruled out)

2. Liver:

  • Hepatomegaly with histological changes
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Cirrhosis

3. Calcium Homeostasis:

  • Thickening of long bones (Option C ruled out)
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Calcification of soft tissues

4. Skin:

  • Excessive dryness
  • Desquamation
  • Alopecia

5. Bone Health:

  • Decreased bone mineral density (Option B)
  • Increased fracture risk
  • Bony exostosis.

6. Pregnancy: Increased risk of teratogenesis: Congenital malformation in developing fetuses.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Vitamin A deficiency is not correct?

choices.text: Causes rough skin and atrophy of epithelial tissues.
Preventable cause of blindness in children under 5.
Increased retinol-binding protein synthesis is a cause

questions.solution:
Causes for Vitamin A Deficiency :

  • Decreased intake.
  • Obstructive jaundice: Defective absorption.
  • Liver cirrhosis: Reduced synthesis of RBP (retinol binding protein).
  • Severe malnutrition: Lack of amino acids for RBP synthesis. (Option D)
  • Chronic nephrosis: RBP excretion through urine.

Vitamin A Deficiency Manifestations :

1. Ocular manifestations:

Vitamin A deficiency is the most significant preventable cause of blindness, especially in children below 5 in developing countries. (Option C ruled out)

Early Signs:

  • Loss of sensitivity to green light.
  • Difficulty adapting to dim light.
  • Night blindness.

Prolonged Deficiency:

a) Xerophthalmia:

  • Dry, thick, keratinized conjunctiva and cornea. If untreated, it leads to corneal ulceration and ultimately results in blindness due to the formation of opaque scar tissue.
  • WHO grading of xerophthalmia:

XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots.

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.

b) Bitot's Spots: Grayish-white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva.

c) Keratomalacia: When xerophthalmia persists for a longer time, it progresses to keratomalacia (corneal softening) (Option B ruled out).
 

2) Immune Function:

  • Deficiency increases susceptibility to infections.
  • Infection reduces retinol-binding protein synthesis, lowering vitamin A levels and impairing immune responses. (Option D)

3) Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions:

  • Follicular Hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): Causes rough skin due to hyperkeratinization of the follicular epithelium.
  • Keratinizing Metaplasia: Affects respiratory, gastrointestinal, and genitourinary tracts.
  • Epithelium is atrophied. (Option A ruled out)

 

4) Other General Manifestation :

  • Growth retardation due to defective synthesis of chondroitin sulfate.
  • Decreased protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman reports difficulty seeing in low light. She has a poor diet, lacking in fruits and vegetables. Dark adaptation is delayed on testing. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin A Deficiency - ↓ Recycling of All-trans-Retinal; ↓ Regeneration of 11-cis-Retinal; ↑ Prolonged Dark Adaptation; ↑ Night Blindness
  • Vitamin A deficiency impairs the recycling of all-trans-retinal and slows the regeneration of 11-cis-retinal, leading to prolonged dark adaptation and night blindness.

Impact of Vitamin A on the Visual Cycle:

Adequate Vitamin A

  • 11-cis-Retinal Availability: With sufficient vitamin A, 11-cis-retinal is readily available to bind with opsin, forming rhodopsin. This is crucial for phototransduction, where light is converted into electrical signals in the retina.
  • Efficient Dark Adaptation: The rapid conversion of 11-cis-retinal to rhodopsin supports quick adaptation to low-light conditions, enabling effective dark adaptation.

 

Adequate Vitamin A: ↑Recycling of All-trans-Retinal; ↑ 11-cis-Retinal & Rhodopsin Formation; ↓ Rapid Dark Adaptation; ↓ Night blindness

Effects of Vitamin A Deficiency

  • Impaired Recycling of All-trans-Retinal: In vitamin A deficiency, the recycling of all-trans-retinal, which detaches from opsin after photon absorption, is impaired. Normally, all-trans-retinal is converted back to 11-cis-retinal through:
    • Retinol Dehydrogenases (RDH): Convert all-trans-retinal to all-trans-retinol.
    • Further Conversion: All-trans-retinol is then converted to 11-cis-retinal.
  • Slower Regeneration: The regeneration of 11-cis-retinal from all-trans-retinol is significantly slowed, leading to:
    • Prolonged Dark Adaptation: The delay in regenerating 11-cis-retinal results in slower adaptation to dark conditions.
    • Night Blindness: The visual system's reduced ability to adjust to low light conditions leads to symptoms such as night blindness.

Impaired retinol storage (Option A) could lead to vitamin A deficiency, but this option is vague and doesn't specifically explain the mechanism affecting night vision. The critical issue in night blindness is the regeneration of 11-cis-retinal, which is directly involved in the visual cycle.

Defective retinoic acid transport (Option C): Retinoic acid is involved in gene expression and cellular differentiation, not in the visual cycle. A defect in its transport would likely lead to other systemic symptoms, not specifically night blindness or delayed dark adaptation.

Accumulation of all-trans-retinal (Option D) could potentially cause oxidative stress, but this is more related to photoreceptor damage rather than the primary issue in night blindness, which is the lack of 11-cis-retinal necessary for vision in low light.

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for the isomerization of all-trans retinyl ester to 11-cis retinol in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)?
questions.solution:
Retinoid isomerohydrolase (RPE65) is the enzyme responsible for the isomerization of all-trans retinyl ester to 11-cis retinol, a crucial step in the visual cycle.


The visual cycle, also known as Wald's visual cycle, involves the conversion of light into electrical signals in the photoreceptors of the retina and the regeneration of visual pigments to maintain visual sensitivity.

 

Phototransduction Process/ Photobleaching
  • Light photons are absorbed by visual pigments (rhodopsin in rods, opsins in cones) in the retina.
  • The absorption of a photon causes the 11-cis-retinal (a chromophore bound to opsin) to isomerize to all-trans-retinal.
  • The isomerization induces a conformational change in the opsin protein, activating it (metarhodopsin II).
  • Activated opsin (metarhodopsin II) ➜ Activates the G-protein transducin ➜ Activates PDE, which hydrolyzes cyclic GMP (cGMP) to GMP.
  • Decreased cGMP levels ➜ Leads to the closure of Na+ channels in the photoreceptor cell membrane ➜ Hyperpolarization ➜ Generation of an electrical signal ➜ Visual pathway ➜ Vision occurs

Visual Cycle Regeneration - Regenerated 11 cis retinal from All-trans retinal

Step

Site

Reaction

Enzyme/Mechanism

1

Photoreceptor outer segment

All-trans-Retinal + NADPH → All-trans-Retinol + NADP+

All-trans-Retinol Dehydrogenase (Option B)

2

Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells.

Transport to retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells.

Cellular Retinoid Binding Proteins

3

Esterification : All-trans-Retinol + Fatty Acyl CoA → All-trans-Retinyl Ester + CoA

Lecithin-Retinol Acyltransferase (LRAT) (Option A)

4

Isomerization and Hydrolysis: All-trans-Retinyl Ester → 11-cis-Retinol

RPE65 (retinoid isomerohydrolase) (Option C)

5

Oxidation: 11-cis-Retinol + NAD+ → 11-cis-Retinal + NADH + H+

11-cis-Retinol Dehydrogenase (Option D)

questions.text: Which form of vitamin A is stored in the liver and must bind to retinol-binding protein (RBP) for transport to other tissues?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Retinol

Explanation:

 

Retinol is the form of vitamin A that is stored in the liver as retinyl esters. For transport to other tissues, retinol must bind to retinol-binding protein (RBP).

Absorption and Transport of Retinoids:

Retinoids

Structurally related molecules with vitamin A activity.

Functions

Vision, reproduction, growth, epithelial tissue maintenance, immune function.

Types of Retinoids

Retinol
  • Primary alcohol containing a ß-ionone ring with an unsaturated side chain
  • Storage form of vitamin A as retinyl ester with long-chain fatty acid.

Retinal

(Option B)
  • Aldehyde derived from oxidation of retinol.
  • Retinal and retinol can readily be interconnected.

Retinoic Acid

(Option C)
  • Acid form derived from oxidation of the retinal.
  • Cannot be reduced in body, so can't give rise to retinal or retinol.
  • Binds to retinoic acid receptors (RARs) in target tissue nuclei.
  • Regulates gene expression by modulating RNA synthesis and protein production.
  • 2 Forms: ATRA & Isotretinoin
  • All-trans Retinoic Acid (ATRA)
  • Promotes growth and differentiation of epithelial cells.
  • Mild acne treated with topical tretinoin (all-trans retinoic acid).
  • Treatment in acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
  • 13-cis Retinoic Acid (Isotretinoin)
  • Suppresses keratinization; used to treat resistant acne and Harlequin ichthyosis.
  • Induces apoptosis in sebaceous glands, reducing sebum production.

Functions of Retinoids

Vision

Essential for visual pigments in rod and cone cells.

Epithelial Cell Maintenance

Supports healthy differentiation and mucus secretion.

Reproduction

Crucial for spermatogenesis and preventing fetal resorption.

Vitamin A Deficiency

Phrynoderma (Follicular Hyperkeratosis)

Small, papillary lesions with keratin plugs on the limbs; impaired suppression of keratinization.

Conjunctival Xerosis

Dry and keratinized conjunctiva; manifests as Bitot's spots (triangular, foamy white or yellowish spots on the sides of the eyes).

 

Beta-carotene (Option D): It is found in plant-based foods, β-carotene is a provitamin A. The human body uses an intestinal enzyme to cleave one beta-carotene molecule to produce two retinal molecules, which can then be reduced to retinol.

Carotenemia is a condition characterized by yellow-orange discoloration of the skin due to elevated levels of carotenoids in the blood, primarily from high dietary intake of carotenoid-rich foods like carrots and sweet potatoes.
